issue.title: Setting enable_installer to false does not disable installer.
issue.body:
This is with the FULL version on 1.4.10

It's false in defaults.inc.php. I'm not sure if that is actually read so I copied the line to config.inc.php

```
<?php
$config['enable_installer'] = false;
```

The installer still comes up with the installer URL entered.

There appears to be a check in index.php in the installer dir but I haven't dug into why this isn't being recognized.

I will just remove the installer dir completely but the config setting is mentioned in the final page of the installer.

comment.body: I too think it might be worth mentioning this in the red text at the bottom.

issue.title: Duplicate BLSession -> BeamCalendar relationship?
issue.body:
There appears to be a duplicate relationship between BLSession -> BeamCalendar, is this correct?

https://github.com/DiamondLightSource/ispyb-database/blob/0ccd996220be28b7a39ee3e226f000e6cbc3901d/schemas/ispyb/tables.sql#L750-L753

The resulting SQLAlchemy ORM class has this relationship duplicated:

https://github.com/DiamondLightSource/ispyb-api/blob/c59197cf8352056148cc9d3aae85c4f176880d0d/src/ispyb/sqlalchemy/_auto_db_schema.py#L2394-L2401

which leads to the following error when using the models:
```
SAWarning: relationship 'BLSession.BeamCalendar1' will copy column BeamCalendar.beamCalendarId to column BLSession.beamCalendarId, which conflicts with relationship(s): 'BLSession.BeamCalendar' (copies BeamCalendar.beamCalendarId to BLSession.beamCalendarId). If this is not the intention, consider if these relationships should be linked with back_populates, or if viewonly=True should be applied to one or more if they are read-only. For the less common case that foreign key constraints are partially overlapping, the orm.foreign() annotation can be used to isolate the columns that should be written towards.   To silence this warning, add the parameter 'overlaps="BeamCalendar"' to the 'BLSession.BeamCalendar1' relationship. (Background on this error at: https://sqlalche.me/e/14/qzyx)
```

comment.body:
This is a bit strange as the update script should have dropped the old constraint:

https://github.com/DiamondLightSource/ispyb-database/blob/0ccd996220be28b7a39ee3e226f000e6cbc3901d/schemas/ispyb/updates/2022_04_12_BLSession_fk_beamCalendarId_set_null.sql#L3-L6

However, running the update script on a the old version of the table does not drop the constraint, and it also does not produce any warning or error message.

Anyway, a statement `ALTER TABLE BLSession DROP CONSTRAINT BLSession_ibfk_3;` does the job. I'll push a new update script to do that.

issue.title: Separate read and read-write database connections
issue.body:
For facilities that want to use database replication, I think it would be useful if we have two separate database connections in the config file:

- One connection for reads (`SELECT`)
- One connection for writes (`INSERT`, `UPDATE`, `DELETE`, `REPLACE`, ...) and or transactions with mixed reads and writes

Galera replication requires read-write splitting, unless you want to deal with unpleasant errors (see e.g. the article [Galera’s big gotcha for MySQL users](https://ghostaldev.com/2016/05/22/galera-gotcha-mysql-users/)). For standard, asynchronous primary-secondary replication it also makes sense to split reads and writes, so you can write to the primary, and read from the secondaries. I think you can configure the MariaDB and MySQL Python connectors to access multiple hosts (secondaries in this case) through a pool.  

It's possible to use a database proxy to do automatic/intelligent read-write splitting, such as MaxScale (which is proprietary - requires a MariaDB support subscription if you have 3 or more nodes) or ProxySQL (which in my experience is difficult to use and has severe limitations, see e.g. [my dba.se question](https://dba.stackexchange.com/questions/303689/how-to-configure-proxysql-with-galera-to-allow-using-user-defined-variables)). 

Therefore, I think we should do this split in the API so that facilities don't necessarily have to invest in costly or difficult-to-use database proxies.

issue.body:
Should this line specify version 8.0.29, just like in requirements.txt?
https://github.com/ispyb/py-ispyb/blob/4d48f7f393c7949ea49956b254783f2e46cca5dc/setup.cfg#L47

comment.body:
I also see that the project depends on `mysql-connector` in addition to `mysql-connector-python`.

Apparently, `mysql-connector` is just an older version of what is now `mysql-connector-python`:
https://github.com/pypi/warehouse/issues/5537

So we should probably remove `mysql-connector` from the `requirements.txt` and `setup.cfg` files.

issue.body:
When trying to open a connection to ispyb I get the following error:
```python

    yield from contingency_wrapper(plan,
  File "/dls_sw/i03/software/artemis/.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/bluesky/preprocessors.py", line 575, in contingency_wrapper
    ret = yield from plan
  File "/dls_sw/i03/software/artemis/src/artemis/fast_grid_scan_plan.py", line 82, in run_gridscan
    with ispyb as ispyb_ids, NexusWriter(
  File "/dls_sw/i03/software/artemis/src/artemis/ispyb/store_in_ispyb.py", line 46, in __enter__
    ) = self.store_grid_scan(self.full_params)
  File "/dls_sw/i03/software/artemis/src/artemis/ispyb/store_in_ispyb.py", line 77, in store_grid_scan
    with ispyb.open(self.ISPYB_CONFIG_FILE) as self.conn:
  File "/dls_sw/i03/software/artemis/.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/ispyb/__init__.py", line 55, in open
    conn = Connector(**credentials)
  File "/dls_sw/i03/software/artemis/.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/ispyb/connector/mysqlsp/main.py", line 30, in __init__
    self.connect(user=user, pw=pw, host=host, db=db, port=port)
  File "/dls_sw/i03/software/artemis/.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/ispyb/connector/mysqlsp/main.py", line 53, in connect
    self.conn = mysql.connector.connect(
  File "/dls_sw/i03/software/artemis/.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/mysql/connector/pooling.py", line 287, in connect
    return MySQLConnection(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/dls_sw/i03/software/artemis/.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/mysql/connector/connection.py", line 137, in __init__
    self.connect(**kwargs)
  File "/dls_sw/i03/software/artemis/.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/mysql/connector/abstracts.py", line 1095, in connect
    self._open_connection()
  File "/dls_sw/i03/software/artemis/.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/mysql/connector/connection.py", line 544, in _open_connection
    self.set_converter_class(self._converter_class)
  File "/dls_sw/i03/software/artemis/.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/mysql/connector/abstracts.py", line 1271, in set_converter_class
    self.converter = convclass(charset_name, self._use_unicode)
  File "/dls_sw/i03/software/artemis/.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/mysql/connector/conversion.py", line 136, in __init__
    MySQLConverterBase.__init__(self, charset, use_unicode, str_fallback)
  File "/dls_sw/i03/software/artemis/.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/mysql/connector/conversion.py", line 59, in __init__
    self.set_charset(charset)
  File "/dls_sw/i03/software/artemis/.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/mysql/connector/conversion.py", line 73, in set_charset
    self.charset_id = CharacterSet.get_charset_info(self.charset)[0]

    info = cls.get_default_collation(charset)
  File "/dls_sw/i03/software/artemis/.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/mysql/connector/constants.py", line 746, in get_default_collation
    raise ProgrammingError(f"Character set '{charset}' unsupported")
mysql.connector.errors.ProgrammingError: Character set 'utf8' unsupported
```
According to https://stackoverflow.com/questions/73244027/character-set-utf8-unsupported-in-python-mysql-connector the fix is to either pin mysql-connector version or use a specific `mariadb` connector.

issue.title: Feature/update php version 7.4
issue.body:
Note, includes js library updates applied in [feature/update-npm-libraries](https://github.com/DiamondLightSource/SynchWeb/tree/feature/update-npm-libraries) - so that should be merged before this one.

This includes fixes to get things working with php7.4.  The UI has been tested in a variety of ways - exercising as much of the functionality as I was aware of.  This exposed to main sets of issues:

i) problems due to invalid regexps - 7.4 has introduced the use of the PCRE2 standard (https://www.pcre.org/current/doc/html/index.html) and this tightens up the handling of regexps - none of the changes made here should therefore be backwards incompatible - they just fix previous re's that were treated more forgivingly.  The main issue is due to the use of '-' in character classes (i.e. between square brackets) - this is a protected character in most cases, so needs escaping - '\-'.

ii) php7.4 seems less forgiving when indexing objects with keys that don't exist - previously these might just return nulls, but now they more likely throw exceptions (although this may just be due to different error settings I've got?).  To fix the issues encountered here, I added a few additional wrapper checks to ensure the keys existed before using them as indices.

Lastly, there was a styling issue due - probably due to the javascript library update introducing a conflict.  This manifested itself in tables with editable columns - the headers for these could be blanked out as white buttons (previously such headings were links, not buttons).  Added a new style to correct this specific issue. 

Note, pdf creation now needs access to a specific temp folder defined in config.php - with access 755.

issue.title: implement SSX fundamentals
issue.body: [SSX_ispyb.docx](https://github.com/ispyb/py-ispyb/files/8916488/SSX_ispyb.docx) provides a list of the fundamental values that we would need to store for SSX experiments. This list can be used as a starting point to build a first SSX prototype in py-ISPyB.

comment.body:
And yes, please consider using `DataCollectionGroup.experimentTypeId` -> `ExperimentType` table, which I think Stu mentioned. There are several advantages to using a lookup table instead of this enum since it has so many enum options now. Although, perhaps that should be its own ticket since it will have impact beyond SSX.

I'm a little bit concerned about the potential size of the `GraphData` table. How many such rows do we expect per `Graph`? An alternative could be to put the xy data in files and reference them through the `DataCollectionFileAttachment` table (fileType = 'xy'). That said, the advantage of storing the data in the database might outweigh the inconvenience of dealing with a potentially big table.

Re: the naming of `Sequence`, `SequenceEvent`, `SequenceEventType`: If we want shorter names, an alternative could be to remove the "Sequence" prefix in the two latter tables. You could also rename `Sequence` to `EventChain` if you think that makes the relationship clearer.
 
Re: the name of `SSXHits`: The number of hits is one value stored in the table, but there are other values as well. So, perhaps we should have a name that is a bit more generic? A name hinting to the fact that the table contains SSX processing results?

issue.title: implement SSX fundamentals
issue.body: [SSX_ispyb.docx](https://github.com/ispyb/py-ispyb/files/8916488/SSX_ispyb.docx) provides a list of the fundamental values that we would need to store for SSX experiments. This list can be used as a starting point to build a first SSX prototype in py-ISPyB.

comment.body:
If the relationship between `DataCollection` and `SAXSDataCollection` is truly 1-to-1, then the PK of  `SAXSDataCollection` should be `dataCollectionId`, and there is no need for `saxsDataCollectionId`.

The same goes for the relationship between `DataCollection` and `SSXHits` - the PK of `SSXHits` should be `dataCollectionId`.

issue.title: Duplicate BLSession -> BeamCalendar relationship?
issue.body:
There appears to be a duplicate relationship between BLSession -> BeamCalendar, is this correct?

https://github.com/DiamondLightSource/ispyb-database/blob/0ccd996220be28b7a39ee3e226f000e6cbc3901d/schemas/ispyb/tables.sql#L750-L753

The resulting SQLAlchemy ORM class has this relationship duplicated:

https://github.com/DiamondLightSource/ispyb-api/blob/c59197cf8352056148cc9d3aae85c4f176880d0d/src/ispyb/sqlalchemy/_auto_db_schema.py#L2394-L2401

which leads to the following error when using the models:
```
SAWarning: relationship 'BLSession.BeamCalendar1' will copy column BeamCalendar.beamCalendarId to column BLSession.beamCalendarId, which conflicts with relationship(s): 'BLSession.BeamCalendar' (copies BeamCalendar.beamCalendarId to BLSession.beamCalendarId). If this is not the intention, consider if these relationships should be linked with back_populates, or if viewonly=True should be applied to one or more if they are read-only. For the less common case that foreign key constraints are partially overlapping, the orm.foreign() annotation can be used to isolate the columns that should be written towards.   To silence this warning, add the parameter 'overlaps="BeamCalendar"' to the 'BLSession.BeamCalendar1' relationship. (Background on this error at: https://sqlalche.me/e/14/qzyx)
```

comment.body:
This is a bit strange as the update script should have dropped the old constraint:

https://github.com/DiamondLightSource/ispyb-database/blob/0ccd996220be28b7a39ee3e226f000e6cbc3901d/schemas/ispyb/updates/2022_04_12_BLSession_fk_beamCalendarId_set_null.sql#L3-L6

However, running the update script on a the old version of the table does not drop the constraint, and it also does not produce any warning or error message.

Anyway, a statement `ALTER TABLE BLSession DROP CONSTRAINT BLSession_ibfk_3;` does the job. I'll push a new update script to do that.

issue.title: Separate read and read-write database connections
issue.body:
For facilities that want to use database replication, I think it would be useful if we have two separate database connections in the config file:

- One connection for reads (`SELECT`)
- One connection for writes (`INSERT`, `UPDATE`, `DELETE`, `REPLACE`, ...) and or transactions with mixed reads and writes

Galera replication requires read-write splitting, unless you want to deal with unpleasant errors (see e.g. the article [Galera’s big gotcha for MySQL users](https://ghostaldev.com/2016/05/22/galera-gotcha-mysql-users/)). For standard, asynchronous primary-secondary replication it also makes sense to split reads and writes, so you can write to the primary, and read from the secondaries. I think you can configure the MariaDB and MySQL Python connectors to access multiple hosts (secondaries in this case) through a pool.  

It's possible to use a database proxy to do automatic/intelligent read-write splitting, such as MaxScale (which is proprietary - requires a MariaDB support subscription if you have 3 or more nodes) or ProxySQL (which in my experience is difficult to use and has severe limitations, see e.g. [my dba.se question](https://dba.stackexchange.com/questions/303689/how-to-configure-proxysql-with-galera-to-allow-using-user-defined-variables)). 

Therefore, I think we should do this split in the API so that facilities don't necessarily have to invest in costly or difficult-to-use database proxies.

https://github.com/ispyb/py-ispyb/blob/4d48f7f393c7949ea49956b254783f2e46cca5dc/setup.cfg#L47

comment.body:
I also see that the project depends on `mysql-connector` in addition to `mysql-connector-python`.

Apparently, `mysql-connector` is just an older version of what is now `mysql-connector-python`:
https://github.com/pypi/warehouse/issues/5537

So we should probably remove `mysql-connector` from the `requirements.txt` and `setup.cfg` files.

issue.title: Feature/update php version 7.4
issue.body:
Note, includes js library updates applied in [feature/update-npm-libraries](https://github.com/DiamondLightSource/SynchWeb/tree/feature/update-npm-libraries) - so that should be merged before this one.

This includes fixes to get things working with php7.4.  The UI has been tested in a variety of ways - exercising as much of the functionality as I was aware of.  This exposed to main sets of issues:

i) problems due to invalid regexps - 7.4 has introduced the use of the PCRE2 standard (https://www.pcre.org/current/doc/html/index.html) and this tightens up the handling of regexps - none of the changes made here should therefore be backwards incompatible - they just fix previous re's that were treated more forgivingly.  The main issue is due to the use of '-' in character classes (i.e. between square brackets) - this is a protected character in most cases, so needs escaping - '\-'.

ii) php7.4 seems less forgiving when indexing objects with keys that don't exist - previously these might just return nulls, but now they more likely throw exceptions (although this may just be due to different error settings I've got?).  To fix the issues encountered here, I added a few additional wrapper checks to ensure the keys existed before using them as indices.

Lastly, there was a styling issue due - probably due to the javascript library update introducing a conflict.  This manifested itself in tables with editable columns - the headers for these could be blanked out as white buttons (previously such headings were links, not buttons).  Added a new style to correct this specific issue. 

Note, pdf creation now needs access to a specific temp folder defined in config.php - with access 755.

issue.title: implement SSX fundamentals
issue.body: [SSX_ispyb.docx](https://github.com/ispyb/py-ispyb/files/8916488/SSX_ispyb.docx) provides a list of the fundamental values that we would need to store for SSX experiments. This list can be used as a starting point to build a first SSX prototype in py-ISPyB.

comment.body:
And yes, please consider using `DataCollectionGroup.experimentTypeId` -> `ExperimentType` table, which I think Stu mentioned. There are several advantages to using a lookup table instead of this enum since it has so many enum options now. Although, perhaps that should be its own ticket since it will have impact beyond SSX.

I'm a little bit concerned about the potential size of the `GraphData` table. How many such rows do we expect per `Graph`? An alternative could be to put the xy data in files and reference them through the `DataCollectionFileAttachment` table (fileType = 'xy'). That said, the advantage of storing the data in the database might outweigh the inconvenience of dealing with a potentially big table.

Re: the naming of `Sequence`, `SequenceEvent`, `SequenceEventType`: If we want shorter names, an alternative could be to remove the "Sequence" prefix in the two latter tables. You could also rename `Sequence` to `EventChain` if you think that makes the relationship clearer.
 
Re: the name of `SSXHits`: The number of hits is one value stored in the table, but there are other values as well. So, perhaps we should have a name that is a bit more generic? A name hinting to the fact that the table contains SSX processing results?

issue.title: implement SSX fundamentals
issue.body: [SSX_ispyb.docx](https://github.com/ispyb/py-ispyb/files/8916488/SSX_ispyb.docx) provides a list of the fundamental values that we would need to store for SSX experiments. This list can be used as a starting point to build a first SSX prototype in py-ISPyB.

comment.body:
If the relationship between `DataCollection` and `SAXSDataCollection` is truly 1-to-1, then the PK of  `SAXSDataCollection` should be `dataCollectionId`, and there is no need for `saxsDataCollectionId`.

The same goes for the relationship between `DataCollection` and `SSXHits` - the PK of `SSXHits` should be `dataCollectionId`.

issue.title: Setting enable_installer to false does not disable installer.
issue.body:
This is with the FULL version on 1.4.10

It's false in defaults.inc.php. I'm not sure if that is actually read so I copied the line to config.inc.php

```
<?php
$config['enable_installer'] = false;
```

The installer still comes up with the installer URL entered.

There appears to be a check in index.php in the installer dir but I haven't dug into why this isn't being recognized.

I will just remove the installer dir completely but the config setting is mentioned in the final page of the installer.

issue.title: Duplicate BLSession -> BeamCalendar relationship?
issue.body:
There appears to be a duplicate relationship between BLSession -> BeamCalendar, is this correct?

https://github.com/DiamondLightSource/ispyb-database/blob/0ccd996220be28b7a39ee3e226f000e6cbc3901d/schemas/ispyb/tables.sql#L750-L753

The resulting SQLAlchemy ORM class has this relationship duplicated:

https://github.com/DiamondLightSource/ispyb-api/blob/c59197cf8352056148cc9d3aae85c4f176880d0d/src/ispyb/sqlalchemy/_auto_db_schema.py#L2394-L2401

which leads to the following error when using the models:
```
SAWarning: relationship 'BLSession.BeamCalendar1' will copy column BeamCalendar.beamCalendarId to column BLSession.beamCalendarId, which conflicts with relationship(s): 'BLSession.BeamCalendar' (copies BeamCalendar.beamCalendarId to BLSession.beamCalendarId). If this is not the intention, consider if these relationships should be linked with back_populates, or if viewonly=True should be applied to one or more if they are read-only. For the less common case that foreign key constraints are partially overlapping, the orm.foreign() annotation can be used to isolate the columns that should be written towards.   To silence this warning, add the parameter 'overlaps="BeamCalendar"' to the 'BLSession.BeamCalendar1' relationship. (Background on this error at: https://sqlalche.me/e/14/qzyx)
```

comment.body:
This is a bit strange as the update script should have dropped the old constraint:

https://github.com/DiamondLightSource/ispyb-database/blob/0ccd996220be28b7a39ee3e226f000e6cbc3901d/schemas/ispyb/updates/2022_04_12_BLSession_fk_beamCalendarId_set_null.sql#L3-L6

However, running the update script on a the old version of the table does not drop the constraint, and it also does not produce any warning or error message.

Anyway, a statement `ALTER TABLE BLSession DROP CONSTRAINT BLSession_ibfk_3;` does the job. I'll push a new update script to do that.

issue.title: Separate read and read-write database connections
issue.body:
For facilities that want to use database replication, I think it would be useful if we have two separate database connections in the config file:

- One connection for reads (`SELECT`)
- One connection for writes (`INSERT`, `UPDATE`, `DELETE`, `REPLACE`, ...) and or transactions with mixed reads and writes

Galera replication requires read-write splitting, unless you want to deal with unpleasant errors (see e.g. the article [Galera’s big gotcha for MySQL users](https://ghostaldev.com/2016/05/22/galera-gotcha-mysql-users/)). For standard, asynchronous primary-secondary replication it also makes sense to split reads and writes, so you can write to the primary, and read from the secondaries. I think you can configure the MariaDB and MySQL Python connectors to access multiple hosts (secondaries in this case) through a pool.  

It's possible to use a database proxy to do automatic/intelligent read-write splitting, such as MaxScale (which is proprietary - requires a MariaDB support subscription if you have 3 or more nodes) or ProxySQL (which in my experience is difficult to use and has severe limitations, see e.g. [my dba.se question](https://dba.stackexchange.com/questions/303689/how-to-configure-proxysql-with-galera-to-allow-using-user-defined-variables)). 

Therefore, I think we should do this split in the API so that facilities don't necessarily have to invest in costly or difficult-to-use database proxies.

comment.body:
I also see that the project depends on `mysql-connector` in addition to `mysql-connector-python`.

Apparently, `mysql-connector` is just an older version of what is now `mysql-connector-python`:
https://github.com/pypi/warehouse/issues/5537

So we should probably remove `mysql-connector` from the `requirements.txt` and `setup.cfg` files.

    with ispyb.open(self.ISPYB_CONFIG_FILE) as self.conn:

    self.conn = mysql.connector.connect(

    return MySQLConnection(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/dls_sw/i03/software/artemis/.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/mysql/connector/connection.py", line 137, in __init__
    self.connect(**kwargs)
  File "/dls_sw/i03/software/artemis/.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/mysql/connector/abstracts.py", line 1095, in connect

    self.converter = convclass(charset_name, self._use_unicode)
  File "/dls_sw/i03/software/artemis/.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/mysql/connector/conversion.py", line 136, in __init__
    MySQLConverterBase.__init__(self, charset, use_unicode, str_fallback)
  File "/dls_sw/i03/software/artemis/.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/mysql/connector/conversion.py", line 59, in __init__

mysql.connector.errors.ProgrammingError: Character set 'utf8' unsupported
```
According to https://stackoverflow.com/questions/73244027/character-set-utf8-unsupported-in-python-mysql-connector the fix is to either pin mysql-connector version or use a specific `mariadb` connector.

issue.title: Feature/update php version 7.4
issue.body:
Note, includes js library updates applied in [feature/update-npm-libraries](https://github.com/DiamondLightSource/SynchWeb/tree/feature/update-npm-libraries) - so that should be merged before this one.

This includes fixes to get things working with php7.4.  The UI has been tested in a variety of ways - exercising as much of the functionality as I was aware of.  This exposed to main sets of issues:

i) problems due to invalid regexps - 7.4 has introduced the use of the PCRE2 standard (https://www.pcre.org/current/doc/html/index.html) and this tightens up the handling of regexps - none of the changes made here should therefore be backwards incompatible - they just fix previous re's that were treated more forgivingly.  The main issue is due to the use of '-' in character classes (i.e. between square brackets) - this is a protected character in most cases, so needs escaping - '\-'.

ii) php7.4 seems less forgiving when indexing objects with keys that don't exist - previously these might just return nulls, but now they more likely throw exceptions (although this may just be due to different error settings I've got?).  To fix the issues encountered here, I added a few additional wrapper checks to ensure the keys existed before using them as indices.

Lastly, there was a styling issue due - probably due to the javascript library update introducing a conflict.  This manifested itself in tables with editable columns - the headers for these could be blanked out as white buttons (previously such headings were links, not buttons).  Added a new style to correct this specific issue. 

Note, pdf creation now needs access to a specific temp folder defined in config.php - with access 755.

issue.title: implement SSX fundamentals
issue.body: [SSX_ispyb.docx](https://github.com/ispyb/py-ispyb/files/8916488/SSX_ispyb.docx) provides a list of the fundamental values that we would need to store for SSX experiments. This list can be used as a starting point to build a first SSX prototype in py-ISPyB.

comment.body:
And yes, please consider using `DataCollectionGroup.experimentTypeId` -> `ExperimentType` table, which I think Stu mentioned. There are several advantages to using a lookup table instead of this enum since it has so many enum options now. Although, perhaps that should be its own ticket since it will have impact beyond SSX.

I'm a little bit concerned about the potential size of the `GraphData` table. How many such rows do we expect per `Graph`? An alternative could be to put the xy data in files and reference them through the `DataCollectionFileAttachment` table (fileType = 'xy'). That said, the advantage of storing the data in the database might outweigh the inconvenience of dealing with a potentially big table.

Re: the naming of `Sequence`, `SequenceEvent`, `SequenceEventType`: If we want shorter names, an alternative could be to remove the "Sequence" prefix in the two latter tables. You could also rename `Sequence` to `EventChain` if you think that makes the relationship clearer.
 
Re: the name of `SSXHits`: The number of hits is one value stored in the table, but there are other values as well. So, perhaps we should have a name that is a bit more generic? A name hinting to the fact that the table contains SSX processing results?

issue.title: implement SSX fundamentals
issue.body: [SSX_ispyb.docx](https://github.com/ispyb/py-ispyb/files/8916488/SSX_ispyb.docx) provides a list of the fundamental values that we would need to store for SSX experiments. This list can be used as a starting point to build a first SSX prototype in py-ISPyB.

comment.body:
If the relationship between `DataCollection` and `SAXSDataCollection` is truly 1-to-1, then the PK of  `SAXSDataCollection` should be `dataCollectionId`, and there is no need for `saxsDataCollectionId`.

The same goes for the relationship between `DataCollection` and `SSXHits` - the PK of `SSXHits` should be `dataCollectionId`.

pull_request.title: Add sampleimage positioners
pull_request.body:
We would like to store one or more `Positioner`s with a `BLSampleImage`, primary to define the z motor position so that rois/pois can be bought back into focus from a sample image where there is no online axis camera.

This table will work both with and without https://github.com/DiamondLightSource/ispyb-database/pull/105 (i'm not ready to deploy the changes in https://github.com/DiamondLightSource/ispyb-database/pull/105 yet at ESRF)

pull_request.title: GridInfo.patches
pull_request.body: Allows a grid/mesh scan to define how many patches it is made up of. On imaging beamlines they are sometimes restricted by the throw of the relevant motors so are forced to conduct multiple gridscans in x,y to cover a larger area ("patches"). By specifying how many patches in x, and y we can properly reconstruct the raw data into maps

pull_request.title: DiffractionPlan.scanParameters
pull_request.body:
As discussed adds `scanParameters` to `DiffractionPlan` which mirrors the column in `DataCollection`. The idea is to store parameters that cannot be described by existing columns or may change with some frequency (a json blob to represent a series of params).

I think Jake uses the `DataCollection` counter-part to store beamline parameters not described by `DataCollection`
